content.title: Electroencephalography (EEG) Basics
content.summary: Non-invasive neurophysiological technique recording electrical activity of the brain from scalp electrodes, essential for diagnosing epilepsy, encephalopathy, and altered consciousness states
key_points: Records summated postsynaptic potentials from cortical pyramidal neurons
Standard 10-20 electrode placement system with 21 electrodes
Normal adult posterior dominant rhythm: 8-13 Hz alpha, attenuates with eye opening
Generalized vs focal abnormalities distinguish epilepsy types
Epileptiform discharges: spikes, sharp waves, spike-wave complexes
Continuous EEG (cEEG) for ICU monitoring of nonconvulsive status
Sensitivity for epilepsy ~50% on routine EEG; increases with sleep deprivation

statement.text: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a non-invasive neurophysiological technique that records electrical activity generated by the cerebral cortex through electrodes placed on the scalp according to the international 10-20 system. It is the primary diagnostic tool for epilepsy, providing evidence of seizure activity and epileptiform abnormalities, and is essential for evaluating encephalopathy, altered consciousness, brain death determination, and monitoring in the ICU setting.
statement.formal: EEG = Scalp recording of cortical electrical activity (1-70 Hz) | Epileptiform = Spikes (<70ms) or Sharp waves (70-200ms) | PDR = 8-13 Hz alpha

explanation.intuition: The EEG detects the electrical 'conversation' happening across millions of brain cells. When neurons fire in synchronized patterns, their combined signals are strong enough to detect at the scalp. Think of it like listening to a stadium crowd - you can't hear individual voices, but you can detect when everyone cheers together. Abnormal patterns occur when groups of neurons fire too synchronously (seizures) or too slowly (encephalopathy).
explanation.key_insight: The EEG records postsynaptic potentials, not action potentials - it reflects the net effect of excitatory and inhibitory inputs on cortical pyramidal neurons. This is why EEG primarily reflects cortical activity and has limited sensitivity for deep structures. Epileptiform discharges represent hypersynchronous neuronal firing that may or may not produce clinical seizures.
explanation.technical_details: Signal amplitude is typically 10-100 microvolts, requiring significant amplification. The 10-20 system ensures standardized electrode placement based on skull landmarks (nasion, inion, preauricular points). Montages (bipolar, referential) affect waveform appearance. Digital EEG allows post-hoc remontaging and quantitative analysis. High-frequency activity (>30 Hz) and low-frequency activity (<1 Hz) can be filtered to reduce artifact.

definitions_glossary.electroencephalography: Recording of brain electrical activity from scalp electrodes, measuring summated cortical postsynaptic potentials
definitions_glossary.ten_twenty_system: International standardized electrode placement based on skull measurements ensuring consistent positioning
definitions_glossary.posterior_dominant_rhythm: The background alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz) seen over posterior regions with eyes closed, attenuating with eye opening
definitions_glossary.alpha_rhythm: 8-13 Hz frequency band, normally dominant over posterior regions during relaxed wakefulness
definitions_glossary.beta_rhythm: 13-30 Hz frequency band, seen with alertness, anxiety, or medication effect (benzodiazepines)
definitions_glossary.theta_rhythm: 4-8 Hz frequency band, normal in drowsiness/sleep, abnormal if focal or excessive in wakefulness
definitions_glossary.delta_rhythm: Less than 4 Hz, normal in deep sleep, abnormal in wakefulness (indicates encephalopathy or focal lesion)
definitions_glossary.epileptiform_discharge: Interictal spike or sharp wave pattern indicative of cortical irritability and seizure tendency
definitions_glossary.spike: Transient waveform with pointed peak, duration less than 70 milliseconds, associated with epilepsy
definitions_glossary.sharp_wave: Transient waveform with pointed peak, duration 70-200 milliseconds, associated with epilepsy
definitions_glossary.spike_wave_complex: Spike followed by slow wave, characteristic of generalized epilepsy syndromes
definitions_glossary.ictal_pattern: EEG changes during an actual seizure, showing rhythmic evolution of activity
definitions_glossary.continuous_eeg_monitoring: Extended EEG recording (hours to days) in ICU for detecting nonconvulsive seizures

pathophysiology.mechanism: EEG signals originate from extracellular current flow generated by synchronized postsynaptic potentials in cortical pyramidal neurons oriented perpendicular to the cortical surface. The dipole created by apical dendritic depolarization produces a measurable voltage difference at the scalp. Only synchronized activity from large cortical areas (>6 cm²) generates detectable signals.
signal_generation: Excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) create dipoles in pyramidal neuron layers
Synchronized activity from thousands of neurons required for scalp detection
Cortical gyri orientation affects signal detection (tangential vs radial)
Deep structures (hippocampus, thalamus) not directly recorded
Volume conduction spreads signals across scalp electrodes

normal_patterns.wakefulness: Alpha rhythm 8-13 Hz posteriorly, attenuates with eye opening; low-amplitude beta anteriorly
normal_patterns.drowsiness: Alpha dropout, increased theta, vertex waves, slow eye movements

epileptiform_abnormalities.spikes: Duration <70 ms, stands out from background, followed by slow wave
epileptiform_abnormalities.sharp_waves: Duration 70-200 ms, similar morphology to spikes
epileptiform_abnormalities.spike_wave_complexes: 3 Hz typical in absence epilepsy; 4-6 Hz in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
epileptiform_abnormalities.polyspike_wave: Multiple spikes before slow wave, seen in generalized epilepsies
epileptiform_abnormalities.lateralized_periodic_discharges: LPDs (formerly PLEDs), associated with acute focal lesions

abnormal_background.generalized_slowing: Diffuse theta/delta indicates encephalopathy (metabolic, toxic, infectious)
abnormal_background.focal_slowing: Regional theta/delta suggests structural lesion or postictal state
abnormal_background.asymmetry: Voltage or frequency differences between hemispheres
abnormal_background.electrocerebral_inactivity: No cerebral activity >2 µV, criterion for brain death determination

clinical_settings.ambulatory_eeg: 24-72 hour home recording for intermittent symptoms
clinical_settings.video_eeg_monitoring: Inpatient epilepsy monitoring unit for seizure characterization
clinical_settings.continuous_eeg: ICU monitoring for nonconvulsive seizures, status epilepticus

activation_procedures.hyperventilation: 3 minutes of deep breathing; may provoke absence seizures or focal slowing
activation_procedures.photic_stimulation: Flashing lights at varying frequencies; may provoke photoparoxysmal response
activation_procedures.sleep_deprivation: Increases sensitivity for detecting epileptiform abnormalities
activation_procedures.sleep_recording: Natural or sedated sleep increases yield

definition.@value: Non-invasive recording of brain electrical activity from scalp electrodes, used for diagnosing epilepsy, encephalopathy, and monitoring altered consciousness

skos.scopeNote: Covers routine EEG interpretation, epileptiform patterns, and clinical applications; excludes advanced quantitative EEG analysis
skos.example: A 25-year-old with witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure undergoes EEG showing 3 Hz generalized spike-wave discharges, confirming diagnosis of idiopathic generalized epilepsy

medicalCode.description: Measurement of Central Nervous Electrical Activity
EEG including recording awake and drowsy

learning_objectives: Describe the neurophysiological basis of EEG signal generation
Identify normal EEG patterns across different states of consciousness
Recognize common epileptiform abnormalities (spikes, sharp waves, spike-wave complexes)
Distinguish focal from generalized EEG abnormalities
Apply EEG findings to clinical epilepsy diagnosis and classification
clinical_pearls: Normal EEG does not exclude epilepsy - sensitivity ~50% on single routine EEG
Generalized 3 Hz spike-wave = absence epilepsy; 4-6 Hz polyspike-wave = JME
Focal slowing without spikes suggests structural lesion, not epilepsy
Beta activity increased by benzodiazepines, barbiturates - drug effect, not abnormal
Triphasic waves with hepatic encephalopathy vs GPDs - look for clinical context
Breach rhythm (increased beta/mu) at craniotomy site is artifact, not abnormal

board_yield.usmle_step1: Moderate - basic EEG physiology, frequency bands
board_yield.usmle_step2: High - epilepsy diagnosis, status epilepticus management
board_yield.usmle_step3: High - EEG interpretation in clinical scenarios
board_yield.neurology_boards: Very High - detailed pattern recognition, epilepsy classification

common_misconceptions: Normal EEG excludes epilepsy (false - interictal EEG sensitivity ~50%)
All spikes indicate epilepsy (false - benign variants exist, e.g., wicket spikes)
EEG can detect deep brain activity well (false - primarily reflects cortical activity)
Continuous EEG is only needed for convulsive seizures (false - nonconvulsive status common in ICU)
